awd_titl_txt: III: Small:  Towards a Theoretical Foundation for Diffusion Source Localization
awd_abstract_narration:
Diffusion processes have been used to model many real-world phenomena, including rumor spreading on the Internet, epidemics in human beings, emotional contagion through social networks, and even gene regulatory processes. Diffusion source localization is to identify the source(s) of a diffusion process based on observations such as the states of the nodes and a subset of timestamps at which the diffusion process reaches the nodes. The solutions to this problem can answer a wide range of important questions and have significant societal and economic impacts. For example, epidemic diseases are great threats to global health. The 2009 H1N1 virus alone resulted in 151,700 to 575,400 deaths globally.  Locating an epidemic source can help identify the transmission media of the disease.  This project develops fundamental theories and effective algorithms for fast and accurate diffusion source localization in large-scale networks and with partial information. The results have immediate applications for identifying patient zero in epidemiology, for tracking the spreading of computer viruses/malware in cyber security, for locating the sources of leaked classified information or rumors in social networks, for identifying infusion hubs of human diseases, etc.
 
Existing research on social networks almost exclusively focuses on deriving realistic but mathematically trackable network models and diffusion models. The problem of locating diffusion sources in realistic networks has not been well studied. The key to accurately locating the diffusion source is to identify characteristics of infection subnetworks that are unique "signatures" of the source. By identifying and leveraging unique source signatures, this project advances the state of the art of diffusion source localization by addressing the following three challenges: (1) On the theory side, this project establishes the fundamental limits of source localization for realistic networks. (2)  On the algorithm side, this project develops a suite of effective and scalable diffusion source detection algorithms whose theoretical properties are well-understood. (3) From the evaluation perspective, this project comprehensively evaluates the proposed source detection algorithms using both simulation studies and real application scenarios.

por.por_cntn:
Diffusion processes have been used to model many real-world phenomena, including rumor spreading on the Internet, epidemics in human beings, emotional contagion through social networks, and even gene regulatory processes. Diffusion source localization is to identify the source(s) of a diffusion process based on observations such as the states of the nodes and a subset of timestamps at which the diffusion process reaches the nodes. The solutions to this problem can answer a wide range of important questions and have significant societal and economic impacts. For example, epidemic diseases are great threats to global health. The 2009 H1N1 virus alone resulted in 151,700 to 575,400 deaths globally.  Locating an epidemic source can help identify the transmission media of the disease.

During the course of this project, we developed both fundamental theories and efficient algorithms related to fast and accurate diffusion source localization. From the theory perspective, our accomplishments include (1) We developed the first fundamental bounds for source localization in nontree networks, including conditions under which we can detect the source with a high probability and conditions under which source detection is impossible. (2) We obtained a fundamental understanding of recovering diffusion history with partial timestamps. We proved the problem is an NP-hard problem and developed a greedy step-by-step reconstruction algorithm with low computational complexity. (3) We developed a theoretical framework based on quickest detection for early misinformation detection.

From an algorithm perspective, our accomplishments include (1) We developed new algorithms to identify diffusion sources, which detect the source with probability one in large-scale random graphs. (2) We developed a greedy algorithm that recovers diffusion history with partial observations. (3) We developed new algorithms with linear computational complexity to identify nodes/edges that have the largest impact on the leading eigenvalues, which are the most influential nodes/edges for information spreading. (4) We also developed a new algorithm for recovering networked coevolving time series based on the networked Kalman filter. Information diffusion in networks can be regarded as a coevolving time series. (5) For misinformation detection, we developed an algorithm named QuickStop that detects misinformation based on edge types with very low computational and memory complexity.

The PIs organized multiple workshops and tutorials to disseminate research results developed under this grant, including a workshop on graph techniques for adversarial activities at IEEE BigData 2018, a workshop on Graph Techniques for Adversarial Activity Analytics at BigData 2019, a tutorial on network science of teams at KDD 2018, and a keynote talk on “Networks-as-a-Context: A New Frontier in Network Mining” at the University of Iowa Computing Conference (UICC) 2020. The PIs have graduated multiple Ph.D. students under the support of this project.
